newsitem.title: USA: US Midwest power rises for post-holiday deliveries.
newsitem.headline: US Midwest power rises for post-holiday deliveries.

text.p: Spot bulk electricity prices in the midwestern U.S. were mostly higher Tuesday, lifted by expectations for higher industrial loads following the holiday.
Temperatures throughout the Midwest are forecast to remain well above-normal through this weekend, with the warmest temperatures as high as 25 degrees above-normal expected late this week.
In the Mid-Continent Area Power Pool (MAPP), peak, non-firm power prices for Thursday delivery were discussed in the $16.00-$17.50 per megawatt hour (MWh) area, up about $1 from Monday.
Off-peak non-firm MAPP power for Thursday was pegged at $10.00-$10.50.
In the Mid-American Interpool Network (MAIN), peak, non-firm power prices for Thursday were still in the $16.00-17.00 range.
MAIN off peak power for Thursday was assessed at $11.50-12.00, but no deals were confirmed done.
Peak, non-firm electricity prices in the East Central Area Reliability Coordination Agreement (ECAR) for Thursday were in the $14.00-15.25 range, up from Monday's range of $13.00-14.00.
For next week delivery, peak, non-firm prices in ECAR were talked in the $18.50-19.50 area.
ECAR electricity prices for off-peak, non-firm delivery were quoted at $10.00-$12.00.
January ECAR prices were in the $21.50-22.00 range, traders said. The February market was pegged at $23.00-23.25.

In the Southwest Power Pool (SPP), where temperatures are expected to climb to as much as 25 degrees above-normal this week, peak, non-firm power prices for Thursday delivery were up about $3-$4 to the $14.00-$15.50 range.
Sources said the return of industrial loads following the holiday boosted prices.
Off-peak prices throughout SPP for Thursday delivery were assessed at $11.00-12.00.
January peak prices in SPP were in the $20.00 area, while the February market was talked in the $23.75-24.50.

Separately, Commonwealth Edison said its 794 megawatt (MW) Dresden 2 nuclear power unit would likely resume full power Wednesday, ramping up from about 40 percent power. Dresden 3 is still scheduled to restart January 13, and 1,040 MW Zion 2 nuclear unit is expected to resume full power later this week.
